His symptoms meet the DSM-5 criteria for panic attacks, and he reports persistent concern about having more attacks and has developed significant behavioural changes (avoidance) because of them. Based on this information and the exclusion of medical causes, what is the most accurate diagnosis?

options.description: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
Social Anxiety Disorder
Panic Disorder with Agoraphobia
Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)

questions.clinical_context: Young Adult, Mental Health, Primary Care
questions.reference: DSM-5 Criteria for Panic Disorder

questions.question: The patient is open to treatment but is fearful of medication side effects. He expresses a preference for non-pharmacological approaches if possible. According to Canadian guidelines for the management of Panic Disorder, what is the most appropriate first-line treatment strategy to propose to this patient?

options.description: A prescription for a benzodiazepine, such as clonazepam, to be used as needed when he feels a panic attack starting.
A referral for psychodynamic therapy to explore the unconscious conflicts driving his anxiety.
A referral for a structured course of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT), which is considered a first-line, evidence-based treatment for Panic Disorder, with or without pharmacotherapy.
Starting a beta-blocker, such as propranolol, to control the physical symptoms of palpitations and sweating.

questions.clinical_context: Young Adult, Mental Health, Primary Care
questions.reference: CANMAT Guidelines

questions.question: After discussing treatment options, the patient agrees to try Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) but also decides he is willing to start a medication due to the severity of his symptoms. He wants a medication that is effective and has a low risk of dependency. What is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological agent to initiate for the long-term management of his Panic Disorder?

options.description: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) like imipramine, due to its proven efficacy.
A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as sertraline or escitalopram, starting at a low dose and titrating up slowly to minimize initial activating side effects.
A benzodiazepine, such as alprazolam, taken on a daily schedule for rapid symptom control.
An atypical antipsychotic, such as quetiapine, as an augmenting agent.

questions.clinical_context: Young Adult, Mental Health, Primary Care
questions.reference: CANMAT Guidelines for Anxiety Disorders

questions.question: When you prescribe the initial low dose of sertraline, the patient asks, "What if this pill makes my anxiety worse? I've heard that can happen." This is a common and valid concern. Which counselling statement is most appropriate to address his concern and promote adherence?

options.description: "That is a very rare side effect, so you likely won't experience it. Just take the medication as prescribed."

"You are right, some people can feel a temporary increase in anxiety or jitteriness when starting an SSRI. That's why we are starting with a very low dose. This feeling usually goes away within the first week or two. If it happens, it's a sign the medication is starting to work, but if it's too bothersome, please call me."
"If you feel worse, you should stop the medication immediately and wait for your CBT appointment."
"Perhaps we should hold off on the medication then and just stick with the therapy referral."

questions.clinical_context: Young Adult, Mental Health/Pharmacology, Primary Care
questions.reference: CANMAT Guidelines for Anxiety Disorders

scenario: A 4-year-old child is brought to your urgent care clinic by a parent. The child has had a high fever (up to 40°C) for five consecutive days. Today, the parent noticed a diffuse, non-blanching maculopapular rash on the child's trunk. On examination, the child is irritable. You note bilateral, non-exudative conjunctivitis, bright red and cracked lips, a 'strawberry' tongue, and erythema and swelling of the hands and feet. A palpable cervical lymph node, about 1.5 cm in diameter, is present on the left side.

questions.question: The patient's presentation is highly concerning for a specific systemic vasculitis. To support the diagnosis and, more importantly, to assess for the most serious potential complication of this condition, what is the most critical next step in the assessment?

options.description: Perform a rapid streptococcal antigen test to rule out scarlet fever.
Order a complete blood count and C-reactive protein to assess the degree of inflammation.
Arrange for an urgent referral to a pediatric centre for an echocardiogram to evaluate for coronary artery aneurysms.
Obtain a urine sample to check for signs of a urinary tract infection.

questions.reference: American Heart Association Guidelines on Kawasaki Disease

questions.question: The child has had a fever for 5 days and presents with four of the five principal clinical features: bilateral conjunctivitis, oral mucosal changes, changes in the extremities, and a rash. The cervical lymphadenopathy is also present. Based on the established diagnostic criteria for this condition, what is the most likely diagnosis?

options.description: Measles (Rubeola)
Scarlet Fever
Kawasaki Disease
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome

questions.reference: American Heart Association Guidelines on Kawasaki Disease

questions.question: You have made a presumptive diagnosis of Kawasaki Disease and have spoken with the on-call pediatrician who has agreed to accept the patient in transfer to the hospital. While awaiting transport, which of the following management actions is appropriate for the Nurse Practitioner to initiate in the urgent care clinic?

options.description: Administer a dose of ibuprofen for the fever and pain.
Initiate a course of oral amoxicillin to treat for a possible bacterial infection.
Administer a dose of oral prednisone to decrease the systemic inflammation.

Provide supportive care, including antipyretics like acetaminophen, and ensure the patient remains hydrated, but defer specific treatments like IVIG or aspirin until the patient is in the hospital setting.

questions.reference: American Heart Association Guidelines on Kawasaki Disease

questions.question: The parent is extremely anxious and asks, "What does this mean? Is my child going to be okay?" The NP knows that the cornerstone of inpatient treatment is to reduce inflammation and prevent coronary artery damage. Which statement accurately describes the standard of care for inpatient management of Kawasaki Disease that the parent can expect?

options.description: The main treatment will be a long course of powerful antibiotics given through an IV.
Treatment primarily involves a single infusion of intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) along with high-dose aspirin, which are given to reduce the risk of heart complications.
The doctors will likely just observe the child in the hospital until the fever and rash go away on their own.
The child will need immediate heart surgery to prevent any long-term problems.

questions.reference: American Heart Association Guidelines on Kawasaki Disease

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care, Discharge Planning, and Documentation
questions.question: Before the child is transferred to the hospital, it is critical for the Nurse Practitioner to communicate effectively with the receiving team. Which of the following components is most essential to include in the verbal and written transfer of care documentation?

options.description: A brief note stating '4-year-old with fever and rash, please assess'.

A detailed summary of the history including the precise duration of fever, a point-form list of the specific Kawasaki Disease criteria met, the patient's vital signs, your presumptive diagnosis, and any actions already taken in the clinic.
Only the patient's demographic information and the parent's contact number.
A copy of the child's immunization record and growth chart.

questions.reference: Blueprint for the Canadian Nurse Practitioner Licensure Exam

scenario: A 65-year-old male with a known 20-pack-year smoking history and a diagnosis of moderate COPD presents to your primary care clinic with a three-day history of worsening shortness of breath. He reports his sputum has changed from its usual white colour to yellow-green, and the volume has increased. He also feels more fatigued and his rescue inhaler is not providing its usual relief. On examination, his respiratory rate is 24 breaths/min, SpO2 is 90% on room air (baseline is 92-93%), and you hear diffuse expiratory wheezes.

questions.question: Based on the patient's history and clinical presentation, you suspect an acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD). To determine the severity of the exacerbation and guide the immediate management plan, which assessment finding is most crucial to ascertain?

options.description: The patient's ability to speak in full sentences and the presence or absence of accessory muscle use.
The specific colour of the patient's sputum.
The brand name of the patient's maintenance inhaler.
A detailed dietary history from the past week.

questions.reference: Canadian Thoracic Society (CTS) COPD Guidelines

questions.question: The patient exhibits all three cardinal symptoms of an AECOPD: worsening dyspnea, increased sputum volume, and increased sputum purulence. His vital signs are stable enough for outpatient management. According to the Anthonisen criteria, which are often used to guide antibiotic therapy in AECOPD, what type of exacerbation does this patient have?

options.description: Type 1 (Severe)
Type 2 (Moderate)
Type 3 (Mild)
Type 4 (Non-infectious)

questions.reference: Canadian Thoracic Society (CTS) COPD Guidelines

questions.question: Given the diagnosis of a Type 1 AECOPD suitable for outpatient management, what is the most appropriate pharmacological management plan to initiate for this patient?

options.description: Increase the frequency of his rescue SABA inhaler and advise him to rest.
A course of oral antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin-clavulanate or doxycycline) and a short course of oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days).
A prescription for an oral cough suppressant and a mucolytic agent.
Immediately switch his maintenance inhaler to a triple therapy combination inhaler.

questions.reference: 2023 CTS COPD Pharmacotherapy Guideline

questions.question: You prescribe the appropriate medications for the AECOPD. To optimize his long-term management and reduce the risk of future exacerbations, a review of his maintenance therapy is warranted. He is currently using only a LAMA inhaler. Given that he has had two moderate exacerbations in the past year, what change to his maintenance therapy should be considered once he has recovered from the current exacerbation?

options.description: Continue with the LAMA monotherapy as it is the safest option.
Step up his therapy to a combination LABA/LAMA inhaler.
Step up his therapy to a combination ICS/LABA inhaler.
Discontinue all maintenance inhalers and manage with a SABA as needed.

questions.reference: 2023 CTS COPD Pharmacotherapy Guideline

questions.question: Before the patient leaves, you want to ensure he understands how to manage his current exacerbation and prevent future ones. He says, "I just want to feel better. I don't know what to do when I can't catch my breath." What is the most effective counselling and educational intervention to provide at this time?

options.description: Provide a detailed explanation of the pathophysiology of COPD.
Reinforce the importance of smoking cessation as the single most important intervention.

Provide him with a written COPD Action Plan that clearly outlines how to use his medications for the exacerbation, signs of worsening that should prompt a call or visit, and when to seek emergency care. Also, review pursed-lip breathing techniques for managing acute dyspnea.
Give him a referral to a pulmonary rehabilitation program to be started immediately.

questions.reference: Canadian Thoracic Society (CTS) COPD Guidelines

question: A 52-year-old female presents to a rural primary care clinic complaining of persistent fatigue and weakness for the past three months. She reports a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and a diet low in red meat. On examination, her conjunctivae appear pale, and her heart rate is 92 bpm. The NP suspects iron deficiency anemia and orders a complete blood count (CBC). Which finding would most strongly support this suspicion?

options.description: Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 72 fL
Platelet count 450 x 10⁹/L
White blood cell count 12 x 10⁹/L

question: A 68-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) arrives at the emergency department with increased shortness of breath over the past two days. He reports a productive cough with yellow sputum and a recent upper respiratory infection. His oxygen saturation is 89% on room air, and he appears distressed. The NP must assess the severity of his COPD exacerbation. Which clinical finding is most indicative of a severe exacerbation?

options.description: Respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute
Use of accessory muscles and inability to speak in full sentences
Peak expiratory flow rate 80% of predicted
Temperature of 37.8°C

question: A 35-year-old female presents to a community clinic with complaints of palpitations and anxiety for the past month. She denies chest pain but reports occasional dizziness and a resting heart rate of 110 bpm on self-monitoring. The NP performs an initial assessment and notes a regular tachycardia on auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to assess her condition?

options.description: Order a chest X-ray
Perform a 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG)
Refer to a cardiologist immediately
Measure blood pressure only

question: A 12-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his parents due to a two-day history of fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the NP observes tonsillar exudates, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and a temperature of 38.5°C. The parents are concerned about streptococcal pharyngitis. According to the Modified Centor Score, which additional finding would increase the likelihood of this diagnosis?

options.description: Presence of a cough
Absence of rhinorrhea
History of recent travel
Mild headache

question: A 75-year-old female with a history of osteoarthritis presents to the clinic reporting worsening knee pain over the past six months. She describes stiffness in the morning lasting over an hour and difficulty walking long distances. The NP performs a physical examination and notes crepitus and limited range of motion in the affected knee. Which assessment tool would be most appropriate to evaluate her functional status?

options.description: Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC)
Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
Timed Up and Go (TUG) test
Beck Depression Inventory

question: A 28-year-old male presents to an urgent care clinic after a minor motor vehicle accident. He reports neck pain and stiffness but no loss of consciousness or neurological symptoms. The NP performs a cervical spine assessment to rule out serious injury. According to the Canadian C-Spine Rule, which finding would indicate a need for imaging?

options.description: Age less than 65 years
Ability to rotate neck 45 degrees bilaterally
Midline cervical tenderness
No history of trauma

question: A 40-year-old female with no significant medical history presents to the clinic with a three-week history of abdominal bloating and early satiety. She denies weight loss or changes in bowel habits but reports mild discomfort in the upper abdomen. The NP considers a broad differential, including gastrointestinal and gynecological causes. Which physical examination finding would most urgently warrant further investigation?

options.description: Soft, non-tender abdomen
Palpable mass in the pelvic region
Mild epigastric tenderness
Normal bowel sounds

question: A 60-year-old male presents to the clinic with a three-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and a dry cough. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and worked in construction for 30 years. On examination, the NP hears fine inspiratory crackles at the lung bases. Chest imaging reveals reticular opacities. Which diagnosis is most consistent with these findings?

options.description: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Pulmonary edema
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
Pneumonia

question: A 45-year-old female presents with a two-week history of right upper quadrant pain that worsens after fatty meals. She reports nausea but no fever or jaundice. An ultrasound reveals gallstones and a thickened gallbladder wall without pericholecystic fluid. Which diagnosis best fits this clinical presentation?

options.description: Acute pancreatitis
Chronic cholecystitis
Acute cholangitis
Peptic ulcer disease

question: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a five-day history of fever, chills, and a productive cough with rusty sputum. He has no chronic medical conditions but reports recent contact with a sick colleague. On examination, his temperature is 38.9°C, and there are bronchial breath sounds in the right lower lung field. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.description: Viral bronchitis
Community-acquired pneumonia
Tuberculosis
Acute exacerbation of asthma

question: A 50-year-old male with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes has a fasting plasma glucose of 8.5 mmol/L and an HbA1c of 7.8%. He is overweight with a BMI of 29 kg/m² and has no other comorbidities. The NP decides to initiate pharmacological therapy in addition to lifestyle modifications. According to Diabetes Canada guidelines, which medication is the most appropriate first-line treatment?

options.description: Metformin
Insulin glargine
Sitagliptin
Glimepiride

question: A 65-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation presents to the clinic for routine follow-up. She is currently on warfarin with an INR of 1.8, below her target range of 2.0-3.0. She reports no bleeding or changes in diet or medication adherence. The NP must adjust her anticoagulation therapy. What is the most appropriate action?

options.description: Discontinue warfarin and start a direct oral anticoagulant
Increase the warfarin dose and recheck INR in one week
Maintain the current dose and recheck INR in one month
Add aspirin to the current regimen

question: A 38-year-old female with a history of migraines presents to the clinic with a severe headache unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics. She describes unilateral throbbing pain with nausea and photophobia, lasting over 12 hours. The NP decides to prescribe an abortive therapy. According to Canadian guidelines, which medication is most appropriate for acute migraine management in this scenario?

options.description: Acetaminophen 1000 mg
Sumatriptan 50 mg
Propranolol 40 mg
Topiramate 25 mg

question: A 70-year-old male with a history of heart failure presents with worsening dyspnea and bilateral leg edema over the past week. His current medications include furosemide 40 mg daily and enalapril 10 mg daily. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and his creatinine has increased from 110 to 150 µmol/L. The NP must adjust his management plan. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.description: Increase furosemide to 80 mg daily
Discontinue enalapril
Add spironolactone 25 mg daily
Refer to a nephrologist immediately

question: A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with a confirmed urinary tract infection (UTI) based on urinalysis showing significant bacteriuria. She is otherwise healthy, non-pregnant, and reports dysuria and frequency for three days. The NP reviews local resistance patterns and decides to prescribe an antibiotic. According to Canadian guidelines, which is the most appropriate first-line treatment for an uncomplicated UTI?

options.description: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg BID for 7 days
Nitrofurantoin 100 mg BID for 5 days
Amoxicillin 500 mg TID for 7 days
Trimethoprim 160 mg BID for 3 days

question: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg despite adherence to amlodipine 10 mg daily. He denies symptoms such as headache or chest pain, and his renal function is normal. The NP considers combination therapy to achieve blood pressure control. According to Hypertension Canada guidelines, which additional medication is most appropriate to add?

options.description: Atenolol 50 mg daily
Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily
Losartan 50 mg daily
Clonidine 0.1 mg BID

question: A 42-year-old male with a 20-pack-year smoking history presents to the clinic for a routine visit. He expresses interest in quitting smoking but is unsure about the best approach. The NP discusses evidence-based cessation strategies and emphasizes the importance of behavioral support. Which of the following is the most effective initial counselling recommendation?

options.description: Use nicotine replacement therapy and set a quit date
Switch to vaping as a safer alternative
Rely solely on willpower to quit cold turkey
Attend a yoga class to manage stress

question: A 33-year-old female presents to the clinic seeking advice on contraception options. She has a history of irregular menstrual cycles and prefers a method that does not require daily administration. The NP reviews her medical history, which is unremarkable, and discusses various contraceptive methods. Which option should the NP recommend as the most suitable based on her preferences?

options.description: Combined oral contraceptive pill
Intrauterine device (IUD)
Condoms
Diaphragm with spermicide

reference: Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada

subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
question: A 67-year-old female is being discharged from the hospital following a hip replacement surgery. She lives alone and has limited mobility, requiring assistance with daily activities for the next few weeks. The NP is responsible for coordinating her discharge plan to ensure a safe transition home. Which component is essential to include in her discharge plan?

options.description: Referral to home care services for support
Prescription for antibiotics prophylactically
Instruction to follow up in six months
Recommendation to avoid all physical activity

subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
question: A 50-year-old male with type 2 diabetes attends a follow-up visit via telemedicine after a recent adjustment to his insulin regimen. The NP documents the encounter in the electronic health record (EHR) to ensure continuity of care. Which element is most critical to include in the documentation to meet Canadian legal and professional standards?

options.description: Patient’s subjective report of symptoms and objective findings
A list of all medications ever prescribed
Personal opinions about the patient’s lifestyle
Abbreviated notes to save time

question: A 38-year-old male presents to a rural clinic complaining of chest pain for the past three hours. He describes the pain as a heavy, squeezing sensation in the center of his chest, radiating to his left arm. He denies any recent trauma but mentions a family history of heart disease. The NP must quickly assess the urgency of his condition. Which initial assessment step is most appropriate to determine if this is a cardiac emergency?

options.description: Perform an electrocardiogram (ECG)
Obtain a detailed dietary history
Check for musculoskeletal tenderness
Measure oxygen saturation only

question: A 62-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the clinic reporting increased shortness of breath over the past two days. She uses a salbutamol inhaler as needed but notes it’s less effective recently. The NP observes her respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. What is the most critical initial assessment to evaluate the severity of her respiratory distress?

options.description: Auscultate lung sounds
Measure peak expiratory flow
Assess for accessory muscle use
Order a chest X-ray

question: A 25-year-old female visits a community clinic complaining of recurrent headaches for the past month. She describes them as throbbing, unilateral, and accompanied by nausea, occurring about twice a week. She has no history of trauma or neurological conditions. The NP suspects migraines. Which assessment finding would most strongly support this suspicion?

options.description: Bilateral tenderness over the sinuses
Photophobia during the headache
Elevated blood pressure
Neck stiffness on examination

question: A 50-year-old male with a history of smoking presents to the clinic with a persistent cough for six weeks. He reports occasional blood-tinged sputum and unintentional weight loss of 4 kg. The NP is concerned about a possible malignancy. Which physical examination finding would most urgently warrant further investigation for lung cancer?

options.description: Clubbing of the fingers
Mild wheezing on auscultation
Slightly elevated respiratory rate
Dry oral mucosa

question: A 33-year-old female presents to the clinic reporting fatigue and palpitations for three weeks. She has no significant past medical history but mentions a recent stressful life event. The NP notes her pulse is irregularly irregular at 110 bpm. Suspecting atrial fibrillation, which assessment is most essential to guide immediate management?

options.description: Measure blood pressure
Perform a 12-lead ECG
Assess thyroid function
Check serum electrolytes

question: A 70-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and difficulty urinating for two days. He has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and reports dribbling and a weak stream. The NP suspects urinary retention. Which physical assessment technique is most appropriate to confirm this suspicion?

options.description: Palpate the bladder for distension
Perform a digital rectal exam
Auscultate bowel sounds
Test for costovertebral angle tenderness

question: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with a five-day history of fever, sore throat, and swollen neck glands. She reports difficulty swallowing and no recent travel. The NP observes enlarged, tender cervical lymph nodes and erythematous tonsils with exudate. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate to assess for a bacterial cause of her symptoms?

options.description: Throat swab for culture
Complete blood count (CBC)
Monospot test
Chest X-ray

question: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of burning epigastric pain that worsens after meals and at night. He denies weight loss or vomiting but admits to occasional NSAID use for back pain. The NP suspects peptic ulcer disease. Which diagnostic finding would most definitively confirm this condition?

options.description: Positive Helicobacter pylori test
Elevated serum gastrin levels
Esophageal pH monitoring
Normal abdominal ultrasound

question: A 30-year-old female reports irregular menstrual cycles and excessive facial hair growth for the past year. She has gained 8 kg despite no change in diet or activity. The NP suspects polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Which diagnostic criterion is most essential to establish this diagnosis according to Canadian guidelines?

options.description: Elevated fasting glucose
Ultrasound evidence of ovarian cysts
Hyperandrogenism and ovulatory dysfunction
Low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)

question: A 65-year-old female presents with progressive memory loss and difficulty finding words over the past six months. Her family reports she repeats questions frequently. The NP suspects Alzheimer’s disease. Which clinical feature is most indicative of this diagnosis rather than normal aging?

options.description: Occasional forgetfulness of names
Impaired short-term memory affecting daily function
Mild difficulty with complex tasks
Slower reaction time in conversations

question: A 48-year-old male with type 2 diabetes presents for a follow-up visit. His recent HbA1c is 8.5%, despite adherence to metformin 1000 mg twice daily. He has no other comorbidities. The NP decides to intensify his treatment. According to Diabetes Canada guidelines, which medication should be added next to improve glycemic control?

options.description: Sitagliptin
Insulin glargine
Acarbose
Glyburide

question: A 60-year-old female with hypertension presents with a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg. She is currently on hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily but reports occasional dizziness. The NP considers adjusting her regimen to achieve target blood pressure. Which option aligns best with Hypertension Canada’s recommendations for this patient?

options.description: Switch to losartan 50 mg daily
Add amlodipine 5 mg daily
Increase hydrochlorothiazide to 50 mg daily
Prescribe a beta-blocker

question: A 35-year-old male is diagnosed with acute uncomplicated cystitis. He reports dysuria and frequency for three days and has no drug allergies. The NP reviews local resistance patterns and Canadian guidelines. Which antibiotic is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?

options.description: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
Nitrofurantoin 100 mg twice daily for 5 days
Amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for 7 days
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 3 days

question: A 52-year-old female with osteoarthritis reports worsening knee pain despite regular acetaminophen use. She asks about additional pain relief options. The NP considers her age, comorbidities, and risk of side effects. Which non-pharmacological intervention should the NP recommend as the most evidence-based adjunct to her current therapy?

options.description: Acupuncture sessions
Supervised exercise program
Hot and cold therapy
Massage therapy

question: A 40-year-old male with persistent asthma experiences frequent exacerbations despite using a medium-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS). The NP reviews his inhaler technique and adherence, which are adequate. According to GINA guidelines, which step should the NP take next to optimize his asthma control?

options.description: Add a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA)
Increase the ICS dose
Prescribe oral corticosteroids
Switch to a leukotriene receptor antagonist

question: A 28-year-old female is diagnosed with mild persistent allergic rhinitis. She reports nasal congestion and sneezing triggered by dust and pollen. The NP aims to recommend an initial treatment with minimal side effects. Based on Canadian guidelines, which option should the NP prescribe as the most appropriate first-line therapy?

options.description: Oral antihistamine
Intranasal corticosteroid
Oral decongestant
Leukotriene receptor antagonist

question: A 45-year-old male with newly diagnosed hypertension expresses anxiety about starting medication. He is worried about side effects and long-term use. The NP aims to build trust and address his concerns effectively. Which counselling approach aligns best with Canadian NP standards for establishing a therapeutic relationship?

options.description: Provide a detailed list of all possible side effects
Use motivational interviewing to explore his concerns
Recommend immediate lifestyle changes only
Reassure him that side effects are rare

question: A 32-year-old female seeks advice on smoking cessation during a routine visit. She smokes 10 cigarettes daily and has mixed feelings about quitting. The NP wants to support her autonomy while encouraging change. Which counselling strategy is most appropriate to initiate a discussion about cessation?

options.description: Describe the health risks of smoking in detail
Ask open-ended questions about her readiness to quit
Prescribe nicotine replacement therapy immediately
Suggest cutting down gradually without a plan

reference: Canadian Action Network for the Advancement, Dissemination and Adoption of Practice-informed Tobacco Treatment

subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
question: A 68-year-old male with heart failure is ready for discharge after a hospital stay for an acute exacerbation. The NP prepares a discharge summary to ensure continuity of care with his primary care provider. Which element is most critical to include in the documentation to prevent readmission?

options.description: Detailed list of all hospital staff involved
Instructions for weight monitoring and diuretic adjustment
General advice to avoid salty foods
Summary of past medical history only

subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
question: A 50-year-old female with type 2 diabetes attends a virtual follow-up after starting insulin therapy. The NP documents the encounter in the electronic medical record (EMR). Which detail must be recorded to meet Canadian documentation standards and ensure safe care transitions?

options.description: Patient’s blood glucose readings and insulin doses
A list of all available community resources
The NP’s personal observations about the patient’s mood
Generic instructions for diet and exercise

question: A 72-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent chest pain for the past two weeks. He describes the pain as a heavy sensation that occurs during physical activity and subsides with rest. His medical history includes hypertension and a 20-pack-year smoking history. The nurse practitioner (NP) suspects angina pectoris. Which physical assessment finding would most strongly corroborate this suspicion?

options.description: A loud systolic murmur at the apex
Relief of pain with deep breathing
Levine’s sign (clenched fist over chest)
Bilateral crackles in the lung bases

question: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic reporting a three-day history of dysuria and increased urinary frequency. She denies fever or flank pain but mentions mild suprapubic discomfort. The NP suspects an uncomplicated urinary tract infection (UTI). Which assessment technique should the NP prioritize to evaluate this patient’s condition?

options.description: Palpation for costovertebral angle tenderness
Obtaining a clean-catch urine sample for urinalysis
Auscultation of the abdomen for bowel sounds
Percussion of the spleen for enlargement

question: A 50-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the clinic reporting worsening dyspnea over the past week. He uses a salbutamol inhaler as needed and mentions increased sputum production. The NP performs a respiratory assessment. Which finding would most indicate an acute exacerbation of COPD?

options.description: Decreased respiratory rate
Wheezing and prolonged expiration
Symmetrical chest expansion
Clear breath sounds bilaterally

question: A 65-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of memory lapses and difficulty concentrating over the past six months. She lives alone and reports occasionally forgetting to turn off the stove. The NP suspects early cognitive impairment. Which standardized tool should the NP use to assess her cognitive function?

options.description: Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9)
Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
Clock Drawing Test alone
Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7)

question: A 10-year-old male presents to the clinic with a two-day history of fever, rash, and irritability. The NP notes a blanching erythematous rash on his trunk and extremities, and the child appears uncomfortable. The parents are worried about a possible infectious cause. Which vital sign should the NP assess first to guide the evaluation?

options.description: Blood pressure
Temperature
Oxygen saturation
Respiratory rate

question: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with a six-week history of fatigue, polyuria, and unintentional weight loss of 5 kg. She denies recent infections or changes in diet. The NP suspects a metabolic disorder based on these symptoms. Which diagnosis is most consistent with this clinical presentation?

options.description: Hypothyroidism
Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Chronic kidney disease
Hyperthyroidism

question: A 60-year-old male presents to the clinic reporting a persistent dry cough and shortness of breath for three months. He has a history of hypertension and a 25-pack-year smoking history. The NP orders a chest X-ray, which shows hyperinflation and flattened diaphragms. Which diagnosis is most likely based on these findings?

options.description: Pulmonary edema
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Pneumothorax
Interstitial lung disease

question: A 55-year-old male with hypertension presents to the clinic with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg despite adherence to lisinopril 20 mg daily. He denies side effects and has no other comorbidities. The NP decides to adjust his antihypertensive therapy. According to Hypertension Canada guidelines, which medication should be added to optimize blood pressure control?

options.description: Metoprolol 50 mg daily
Amlodipine 5 mg daily
Spironolactone 25 mg daily
Furosemide 40 mg daily

question: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with an acute asthma exacerbation. She reports wheezing and dyspnea for the past 12 hours, unrelieved by her salbutamol inhaler. Her peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) is 60% of her personal best. The NP initiates treatment. Which medication should be administered first according to Canadian guidelines?

options.description: Oral prednisone
Inhaled salbutamol via nebulizer
Montelukast 10 mg
Ipratropium bromide

question: A 68-year-old female with osteoporosis presents to the clinic for follow-up. She has been taking alendronate 70 mg weekly for one year but reports new epigastric pain. A recent bone density scan shows stable T-scores. The NP considers modifying her treatment plan. Which management option is most appropriate given her symptoms?

options.description: Continue alendronate and add a proton pump inhibitor
Switch to denosumab 60 mg subcutaneously every 6 months
Increase alendronate to 70 mg twice weekly
Discontinue all osteoporosis medications

question: A 40-year-old male with allergic rhinitis presents to the clinic reporting persistent nasal congestion and sneezing despite using over-the-counter antihistamines. His symptoms interfere with sleep and work. The NP decides to prescribe a medication. Which option is most appropriate as first-line therapy according to Canadian guidelines?

options.description: Oral cetirizine
Intranasal fluticasone
Montelukast
Oral pseudoephedrine

question: A 52-year-old male with newly diagnosed hypertension presents to the clinic for a follow-up visit. He has started lisinopril but is hesitant to continue due to concerns about long-term medication use. He asks about non-pharmacological options to manage his blood pressure. Which counselling approach should the NP prioritize to address his concerns effectively?

options.description: Advise immediate discontinuation of lisinopril
Discuss lifestyle modifications including diet and exercise
Recommend herbal supplements as an alternative
Dismiss his concerns and emphasize medication adherence

question: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic requesting advice on weight management. She has a BMI of 32 kg/m² and a family history of type 2 diabetes. She is motivated to make changes but unsure where to start. The NP provides evidence-based counselling. Which recommendation is most appropriate to initiate her weight loss plan?

options.description: Begin a low-carbohydrate diet with a caloric deficit
Start a fasting regimen 5 days per week
Use over-the-counter weight loss pills
Focus solely on high-intensity exercise

subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
question: A 75-year-old male with chronic heart failure is being discharged from the hospital after a four-day admission for fluid overload. He is prescribed furosemide and an ACE inhibitor. The NP prepares his discharge summary. Which element is most essential to document to ensure continuity of care in the community?

options.description: List of hospital meal preferences
Current medication doses and follow-up plan
Names of all consulting physicians
General advice to rest at home

subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
question: A 45-year-old female with type 2 diabetes attends a clinic visit after a recent emergency department visit for hyperglycemia. She is now on metformin and insulin. The NP updates her electronic medical record (EMR). Which detail must be included to comply with Canadian documentation standards for safe care transitions?

options.description: Her recent blood glucose readings and insulin adjustments
A summary of her social hobbies
Generic dietary recommendations
The NP’s personal notes on her demeanor

scenario: Mrs. Johnson, a 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes, presents to the clinic complaining of increased thirst and frequent urination over the past two weeks. She has been taking metformin 500 mg twice daily but admits to occasionally missing doses. Her last HbA1c was 8.2% three months ago. She also mentions feeling more tired than usual and has noticed some tingling in her feet.

options.description: Order a repeat HbA1c test
Perform a point-of-care blood glucose test
Schedule a fundoscopic examination
Refer her for a neurological assessment

questions.reference: Diabetes Canada Clinical Practice Guidelines 2023

options.description: Test for loss of protective sensation using a monofilament
Measure ankle-brachial index
Perform a straight leg raise test
Assess for pedal edema

questions.reference: Diabetes Canada Clinical Practice Guidelines 2023

options.description: Hypoglycemia
Hyperglycemia
Urinary tract infection
Diabetic ketoacidosis

questions.reference: Diabetes Canada Clinical Practice Guidelines 2023

options.description: Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily and reassess in three months
Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily
Add a second oral antihyperglycemic agent
Initiate basal insulin therapy

questions.reference: Diabetes Canada Clinical Practice Guidelines 2023

options.description: "It's important to take your medication as prescribed to control your blood sugar."
"Let's explore what makes it difficult for you to take your medication regularly."
"If you don't take your medication, your diabetes will get worse."
"I can prescribe a different medication if this one is too hard to remember."

questions.reference: Motivational Interviewing in Healthcare, 2020

question: 1. A 68-year-old male presents to your primary care clinic with a 3-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and bilateral ankle edema. He reports orthopnea requiring 3 pillows at night and occasional paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and a 40-pack-year smoking history (quit 5 years ago). On examination, you note JVP elevated to 8 cm above the sternal angle, bilateral crackles to mid-lung fields, and 2+ pitting edema to mid-shins bilaterally. Which combination of initial investigations would be MOST appropriate to order at this visit?

options.description: CBC, electrolytes, creatinine, TSH, troponin, BNP, ECG, chest X-ray
CBC, liver enzymes, lipid profile, HbA1c, ECG, echocardiogram
Arterial blood gas, D-dimer, troponin, CT pulmonary angiogram
CBC, urinalysis, urine protein/creatinine ratio, renal ultrasound

question: 2. A 42-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of fatigue, weight gain of 8 kg, constipation, and feeling cold all the time. She mentions her menstrual periods have become heavier and more irregular. On examination, you notice dry skin, thinning of the lateral eyebrows, and a slightly enlarged thyroid gland that feels firm but non-tender. Her vital signs show BP 138/88, HR 58, temperature 36.2°C. When conducting a review of systems specific to thyroid dysfunction, which additional symptoms would be MOST important to explore to support your clinical suspicion?

options.description: Heat intolerance, palpitations, tremor, and diarrhea
Hair loss, hoarse voice, muscle cramps, and depression
Chest pain, shortness of breath, and peripheral edema
Polyuria, polydipsia, blurred vision, and weight loss

question: 3. During a routine well-child visit, you are assessing a 4-year-old boy whose parents express concern about his behavior at preschool. The teacher reports he has difficulty sitting still during circle time, frequently interrupts others, and has trouble waiting his turn. At home, parents note he's always 'on the go' and has difficulty following multi-step instructions. Before considering ADHD as a diagnosis, which assessment approach would be MOST appropriate according to best practice guidelines?

options.description: Order comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, and lead levels before behavioral assessment
Immediately refer to pediatric psychiatry for medication evaluation
Obtain standardized behavior rating scales from both parents and teachers, conduct developmental screening, and assess for comorbidities
Recommend behavioral therapy only and reassess in 6 months

question: 4. A 35-year-old Indigenous woman presents for her first prenatal visit at 10 weeks gestation. She has a history of gestational diabetes in her previous pregnancy 3 years ago and a family history of type 2 diabetes. Her pre-pregnancy BMI was 32 kg/m². When planning her prenatal screening schedule, considering her risk factors and current Canadian guidelines, when should you order the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) for gestational diabetes screening?

options.description: Immediately at first prenatal visit and repeat at 24-28 weeks if initial test is negative
Only at 24-28 weeks as per routine screening
At 16-18 weeks and repeat at 28-32 weeks
No screening needed if HbA1c is less than 6.5%

question: 5. A 28-year-old male presents with acute onset of severe scrotal pain that woke him from sleep 3 hours ago. He reports nausea and has vomited once. On examination, the left testicle is elevated, extremely tender, and the cremasteric reflex is absent. His temperature is 37.8°C. Given the clinical presentation and time-sensitive nature of the suspected condition, what is the MOST appropriate immediate action?

options.description: Order urgent scrotal ultrasound with Doppler and await results before further action
Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected epididymitis and reassess in 24 hours
Provide analgesia and immediate referral to emergency department for surgical evaluation
Perform manual detorsion attempt in office before considering referral

question: 6. An 82-year-old woman is brought to your clinic by her daughter who is concerned about her mother's memory. The daughter reports her mother has been getting lost while driving in familiar areas, forgetting to pay bills, and recently left the stove on overnight. The patient denies any problems and insists she's 'just getting older.' During your assessment, which validated screening tool would be MOST appropriate to administer initially in the primary care setting?

options.description: Comprehensive neuropsychological battery testing
Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) or Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
CT head scan followed by geriatric psychiatry referral
Clock drawing test alone

question: 7. A 19-year-old female university student presents with concerns about her eating habits. She reports restricting her food intake, exercising 2-3 hours daily, and feeling 'huge' despite others telling her she looks thin. Her BMI is 17.2 kg/m². She admits to using laxatives occasionally and missing her menstrual periods for the past 4 months. When conducting a comprehensive assessment for suspected eating disorder, which physiological parameters require immediate evaluation due to potential life-threatening complications?

options.description: Serum ferritin and vitamin B12 levels only
Complete thyroid panel and cortisol levels
Electrolytes, ECG, orthostatic vital signs, and complete blood count
Bone density scan and growth hormone levels

clinical_context: Young Adult, Mental Health, Primary Care
reference: Canadian Practice Guidelines for Eating Disorders 2020

question: 8. A 55-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of epigastric pain that improves with eating and worsens 2-3 hours after meals. He reports occasional dark, tarry stools and has been using ibuprofen regularly for chronic knee pain. He has a 20-year history of smoking. His hemoglobin is 102 g/L (previously 145 g/L one year ago). Based on this presentation and considering current Canadian guidelines for H. pylori testing, which diagnostic approach would be MOST appropriate?

options.description: Urea breath test for H. pylori and treat if positive
Empiric PPI therapy for 8 weeks and reassess
Urgent referral for upper endoscopy with biopsy
Stool antigen test for H. pylori and CBC monitoring

question: 9. A 6-year-old child presents with a 2-day history of fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, you note pharyngeal erythema, tonsillar exudate, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and absence of cough. The child has no known drug allergies. Using the modified Centor criteria, the score is 4. What is the MOST appropriate next step in establishing the diagnosis?

options.description: Empirically treat with amoxicillin based on high clinical probability
Perform rapid antigen detection test (RADT) for Group A Streptococcus
Order throat culture and await results before treatment
Prescribe supportive care only as likely viral pharyngitis

question: 10. A 45-year-old woman with well-controlled asthma on low-dose ICS/LABA presents with worsening dyspnea over 3 months despite good adherence to therapy. She now experiences breathlessness walking up one flight of stairs. Spirometry shows FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65 with minimal bronchodilator response. She has a 25-pack-year smoking history (quit 2 years ago). What is the MOST likely diagnosis explaining her current presentation?

options.description: Severe persistent asthma requiring step-up therapy
Asthma-COPD overlap syndrome (ACOS)
Exercise-induced bronchospasm
Medication non-adherence with poor inhaler technique

question: 11. A 72-year-old male with newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4 and HAS-BLED score of 2. His creatinine clearance is 45 mL/min, and he has no history of bleeding. He takes amlodipine for hypertension and atorvastatin for dyslipidemia. According to current Canadian cardiovascular guidelines, which anticoagulation strategy would be MOST appropriate?

options.description: Warfarin with target INR 2-3 due to renal impairment
Apixaban 5 mg PO BID
Apixaban 2.5 mg PO BID with dose reduction for renal function
ASA 81 mg daily given bleeding risk

question: 12. A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents for routine follow-up. Her HbA1c is 8.2% on metformin 1000 mg BID. She has a BMI of 34 kg/m², eGFR of 72 mL/min/1.73m², and a history of myocardial infarction 2 years ago. Her insurance covers medications, and she's motivated to improve her control. Based on current Diabetes Canada guidelines, which medication would be the MOST appropriate to add?

options.description: Gliclazide 80 mg daily
Sitagliptin 100 mg daily
Empagliflozin 10 mg daily
NPH insulin 10 units at bedtime

question: 13. An 8-year-old child weighing 25 kg presents with acute otitis media. Examination reveals a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks. The child has no drug allergies and no antibiotics in the past 3 months. The parents prefer to avoid antibiotics if possible. According to Canadian guidelines, what is the MOST appropriate management approach?

options.description: Prescribe amoxicillin 45 mg/kg/day divided BID for 5 days
Provide a wait-and-see prescription for amoxicillin with instructions to fill if no improvement in 48-72 hours
Prescribe amoxicillin 90 mg/kg/day divided BID for 10 days
Recommend acetaminophen and ibuprofen only with follow-up in 48 hours

question: 14. A 32-year-old woman with moderate persistent asthma currently uses budesonide/formoterol 200/6 mcg one puff BID. She reports using her reliever inhaler (salbutamol) 4-5 times per week and waking at night with symptoms twice weekly. Her technique is good, and she's adherent to therapy. According to GINA 2024 guidelines, what is the MOST appropriate step in her management?

options.description: Add montelukast 10 mg daily to current regimen
Increase budesonide/formoterol to 2 puffs BID
Switch to budesonide/formoterol as both maintenance and reliever therapy (MART)
Add tiotropium 2.5 mcg daily via soft mist inhaler

question: 15. A 78-year-old man in long-term care has moderate Alzheimer's dementia and exhibits increasing agitation, especially during evening care routines. He has pushed caregivers twice this week. Non-pharmacological interventions have been optimized. His medications include donepezil 10 mg daily and metoprolol 50 mg BID. Which pharmacological intervention would be MOST appropriate as initial therapy?

options.description: Haloperidol 0.5 mg PO BID scheduled
Risperidone 0.25 mg PO daily at 4 PM
Lorazepam 0.5 mg PO TID scheduled
Trazodone 25 mg PO at bedtime

clinical_context: Older Adult, Mental Health, Long-term Care
reference: CCSMH Canadian Guidelines Behavioral Symptoms Dementia 2023

question: 16. A 26-year-old woman requests emergency contraception after unprotected intercourse 36 hours ago. She has a BMI of 32 kg/m², regular 28-day cycles, and her last menstrual period started 12 days ago. She has no contraindications to hormonal methods. Based on current evidence and Canadian guidelines, which emergency contraceptive option would be MOST effective?

options.description: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg PO as a single dose
Copper IUD insertion within 5 days
Ulipristal acetate 30 mg PO as a single dose
Levonorgestrel 3 mg PO as a single dose due to BMI

clinical_context: Young Adult, Reproductive Health, Primary Care

question: 17. A 48-year-old Indigenous man with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes expresses frustration about lifestyle changes, stating 'My grandmother lived to 89 eating traditional foods and never exercised.' He's reluctant to start metformin, preferring traditional medicine approaches. Using culturally safe counselling techniques, which response would BEST facilitate a therapeutic relationship while addressing his healthcare needs?

options.description: Explain that modern lifestyles require different approaches than his grandmother's generation
Explore his understanding of traditional foods and medicines, acknowledging their value while discussing how they might complement conventional diabetes management
Provide statistics about diabetes complications to emphasize the importance of medication
Refer him to an endocrinologist who can better explain the need for metformin

question: 18. A 22-year-old university student presents requesting help with cannabis use. He smokes marijuana daily to manage anxiety and help with sleep but is concerned about his grades dropping and difficulty concentrating. He's tried to quit several times but experiences irritability and insomnia. Using harm reduction principles, which counselling approach would be MOST appropriate?

options.description: Insist on complete abstinence and refer to addiction services immediately
Explore his readiness to change, discuss gradual reduction strategies, and offer support for managing withdrawal symptoms while addressing underlying anxiety
Prescribe zopiclone for sleep and refer to psychiatry for anxiety management
Advise switching to CBD-only products as they have no psychoactive effects

clinical_context: Young Adult, Mental Health, Primary Care

question: 19. An 85-year-old woman with moderate dementia, diabetes, and heart failure is being discharged from hospital after treatment for pneumonia. She lives alone with home care support twice daily. Her daughter works full-time but is involved in her care. Which discharge planning element is MOST critical to prevent readmission within 30 days?

options.description: Scheduling a follow-up appointment with her family physician within 7 days
Ensuring medication reconciliation with clear instructions for the daughter and home care providers, including a simplified medication schedule
Providing the daughter with a copy of the hospital discharge summary
Arranging increased home care to three times daily

reference: Canadian Patient Safety Institute Medication Reconciliation 2023

question: 20. You are conducting a virtual visit with a 40-year-old woman who reports new onset severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness that started 2 hours ago. She has no significant past medical history. Her home blood pressure monitor shows 156/94 mmHg. Based on virtual care limitations and patient safety considerations, what is the MOST appropriate action?

options.description: Prescribe sumatriptan 100 mg PO and schedule in-person follow-up tomorrow
Order urgent CT head and advise to go for imaging today
Advise immediate emergency department assessment given red flags requiring urgent in-person evaluation
Prescribe naproxen 500 mg PO BID and monitor symptoms over video

question: 1. A 16-year-old female competitive swimmer presents with a 4-week history of progressive fatigue, decreased athletic performance, and feeling cold despite warm weather. She reports heavy menstrual periods lasting 7-8 days and follows a vegetarian diet. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctivae, brittle nails with koilonychia, and a resting heart rate of 110 bpm. Her coach mentions she seems less focused during practice. Which combination of laboratory investigations would be MOST appropriate to order initially to guide diagnosis and management?

options.description: CBC with differential, ferritin, serum iron, TIBC, and TSH
CBC only and treat empirically with iron supplements
CBC, comprehensive metabolic panel, and ECG
Ferritin, B12, folate, and transferrin saturation only

question: 2. A 62-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder (in remission for 6 months) presents with burning pain in both feet, worse at night, and difficulty with balance. He reports numbness in a 'stocking' distribution and has fallen twice in the past month. His current medications include thiamine and folate supplements. On examination, you note absent ankle reflexes bilaterally and decreased vibration sense. When conducting a comprehensive assessment for peripheral neuropathy, which additional evaluations would be MOST important to perform?

options.description: Romberg test, monofilament testing, orthostatic vitals, and nutritional assessment including B12 levels
MRI spine, EMG/nerve conduction studies immediately
Ankle-brachial index and arterial Doppler studies
Psychiatric assessment for depression and anxiety only

question: 3. A 3-year-old boy is brought in by his parents who are concerned about his speech development. He uses about 20 single words but no two-word phrases, points to communicate, and becomes frustrated when not understood. He makes good eye contact, enjoys playing with other children, and meets all gross motor milestones. His hearing screen at birth was normal. Before referring for speech therapy, which assessment would be MOST important to complete first?

options.description: Comprehensive developmental screening using a validated tool like Ages and Stages Questionnaire
Immediate referral to developmental pediatrics without further assessment
Formal audiometry testing to rule out hearing loss
MRI brain to rule out structural abnormalities

question: 4. A 52-year-old perimenopausal woman presents with complaints of irregular periods, hot flashes, night sweats, mood swings, and vaginal dryness affecting her relationship. She has a history of treated breast cancer 5 years ago (ER/PR positive) and is concerned about hormone therapy. Her mother had osteoporosis with hip fracture at age 70. When conducting a comprehensive menopause assessment, which screening evaluations should be prioritized given her risk factors?

options.description: FSH, estradiol levels, and endometrial biopsy
Bone density scan, lipid profile, and validated menopause symptom questionnaire
Mammogram, pelvic ultrasound, and CA-125
TSH only as symptoms might be thyroid-related

question: 5. A 25-year-old male presents to your walk-in clinic with sudden onset of severe, sharp left-sided chest pain and mild dyspnea that started while playing basketball 2 hours ago. He is tall and thin (BMI 19), has no cardiac risk factors, and vital signs show: BP 125/75, HR 96, RR 20, O2 sat 94% on room air. The pain worsens with deep inspiration. Given the presentation and need to rule out life-threatening conditions, what is the MOST appropriate initial assessment approach?

options.description: Order D-dimer and if positive, proceed to CT pulmonary angiogram
Perform focused cardiovascular and respiratory exam, obtain ECG and chest X-ray
Apply Wells criteria and PERC rule before any imaging
Immediate transfer to emergency department without initial workup

question: 6. An 11-month-old infant is brought in for evaluation of recurrent wheezing episodes. The mother reports 4 episodes in the past 6 months, usually associated with upper respiratory infections. Between episodes, the child is well with normal growth and development. Family history is positive for asthma (father) and eczema (older sibling). Physical examination today shows mild expiratory wheeze but no distress. Which assessment tool would be MOST helpful in predicting the likelihood of persistent asthma?

options.description: Modified Asthma Predictive Index (mAPI) incorporating major and minor criteria
Chest X-ray to look for hyperinflation
Trial of bronchodilator therapy response
Serum IgE levels and specific allergen testing

question: 7. A 38-year-old woman presents requesting screening for sexually transmitted infections. She has a new partner and reports inconsistent condom use. She has no symptoms but is concerned after learning her ex-partner was diagnosed with chlamydia. Her last screening was 2 years ago. She has an IUD for contraception and no drug allergies. According to current Canadian STI guidelines, which comprehensive screening approach would be MOST appropriate?

options.description: Urine NAAT for chlamydia and gonorrhea only since she's asymptomatic
Urine NAAT for CT/GC, HIV serology, syphilis serology, and hepatitis B and C screening
Vaginal swab for CT/GC and blood work only if symptoms develop
Pap test with HPV co-testing plus STI bloodwork

question: 8. A 50-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of progressive difficulty swallowing, starting with solids and now including liquids. He has lost 15 kg and reports food 'sticking' in his mid-chest. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history and drinks 3-4 beers daily. Physical examination reveals temporal wasting and a BMI of 18.5. His hemoglobin is 95 g/L. Based on this presentation and red flag symptoms, what is the MOST appropriate diagnostic approach?

options.description: Barium swallow as initial test followed by endoscopy if abnormal
Urgent referral for upper endoscopy with biopsy
CT chest and abdomen to evaluate for malignancy
Trial of high-dose PPI therapy for 8 weeks

question: 9. A 7-year-old girl presents with a 3-week history of facial puffiness, particularly around the eyes in the morning, and decreased urine output. Parents report her urine appears 'foamy.' She had strep throat 4 weeks ago treated with amoxicillin. On examination, you note periorbital edema, 1+ pitting edema of both ankles, and BP 118/78 (95th percentile for age). Urinalysis shows 4+ protein, no blood. Which diagnosis is MOST likely given this clinical presentation?

options.description: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
Minimal change nephrotic syndrome
IgA nephropathy
Henoch-Schönlein purpura nephritis

question: 10. A 65-year-old woman with osteoarthritis presents with acute onset of severe right knee pain, swelling, and warmth that started yesterday. She denies trauma or fever. She takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension and occasional NSAIDs for joint pain. On examination, the knee is erythematous, warm, with a large effusion and limited range of motion due to pain. Her temperature is 37.2°C. Which diagnostic test would be MOST definitive in establishing the diagnosis?

options.description: Serum uric acid level
Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis including crystal examination
X-ray of the knee
C-reactive protein and ESR

question: 11. A 10-year-old boy with moderate persistent asthma is currently on fluticasone 125 mcg BID. Despite good adherence and inhaler technique, he continues to use salbutamol 5-6 times per week and missed school twice last month due to asthma. His mother is concerned about increasing steroid doses. According to current Canadian pediatric asthma guidelines, what is the MOST appropriate next step in management?

options.description: Increase fluticasone to 250 mcg BID
Continue current dose and add salmeterol 50 mcg BID
Add montelukast 5 mg daily to current regimen
Switch to combination budesonide/formoterol 200/6 mcg BID

question: 12. A 74-year-old woman with hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and mild cognitive impairment lives alone. She's currently on 8 medications including metformin, gliclazide, ramipril, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, aspirin, and donepezil. Her daughter reports finding expired medications and duplicates in her mother's home. Her recent HbA1c is 6.8%, BP 128/76. When implementing medication optimization and deprescribing principles, which intervention would be MOST appropriate?

options.description: Stop all diabetes medications since HbA1c is at target
Discontinue gliclazide due to hypoglycemia risk in elderly, continue metformin, and simplify regimen with combination pills where possible
Refer to geriatrician before making any changes
Switch to insulin for better diabetes control

question: 13. A 34-year-old woman with Crohn's disease in remission on adalimumab presents for routine follow-up. She's planning pregnancy and asks about medication management. Her last flare was 18 months ago. She's currently taking adalimumab 40 mg subcutaneously every 2 weeks, folic acid 5 mg daily, and vitamin D. According to current inflammatory bowel disease and pregnancy guidelines, what is the MOST appropriate management plan?

options.description: Discontinue adalimumab immediately due to pregnancy risks
Continue adalimumab throughout pregnancy and discontinue at 30 weeks gestation
Switch to prednisone for disease control during pregnancy
Continue current regimen including adalimumab throughout pregnancy and breastfeeding

question: 14. A 6-year-old boy weighing 20 kg is diagnosed with primary nocturnal enuresis. He wets the bed 5-6 nights per week despite fluid restriction and scheduled voiding. Parents have tried reward charts without success. He's motivated to attend sleepovers but embarrassed about bedwetting. Physical exam and urinalysis are normal. What is the MOST appropriate initial pharmacological intervention?

options.description: Oxybutynin 5 mg at bedtime
Desmopressin 0.2 mg sublingual at bedtime
Imipramine 25 mg at bedtime
Tolterodine 1 mg twice daily

question: 15. A 48-year-old man with newly diagnosed COPD (post-bronchodilator FEV1 65% predicted, CAT score 12) continues to smoke 1 pack daily despite previous quit attempts. He works in construction and reports dyspnea when climbing stairs. He's motivated to improve his breathing but struggles with nicotine cravings. Based on current COPD guidelines, which initial management approach would be MOST comprehensive?

options.description: LAMA monotherapy and referral to respiratory therapy
LABA/LAMA combination, smoking cessation pharmacotherapy with varenicline, and referral to pulmonary rehabilitation
ICS/LABA combination and nicotine replacement therapy
Short-acting bronchodilators PRN and behavioral counseling only

question: 16. A 15-year-old female presents with severe facial acne including numerous papules, pustules, and some nodules on both cheeks and forehead. She's tried over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide and salicylic acid without improvement. She's very self-conscious and avoiding social activities. She's sexually active with one partner and uses condoms. According to current acne management guidelines, which treatment option would be MOST appropriate?

options.description: Topical tretinoin 0.025% nightly and clindamycin gel twice daily
Oral doxycycline 100 mg daily with topical benzoyl peroxide
Combined oral contraceptive containing drospirenone plus topical retinoid
Isotretinoin with appropriate iPLEDGE enrollment and monitoring

question: 17. A 35-year-old woman diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder 6 months ago has been taking escitalopram 10 mg daily with good response. She now presents stating she's been feeling much better and stopped her medication 2 weeks ago. She's experiencing return of anxiety symptoms, insomnia, and 'brain zaps.' She asks if she really needs medication long-term. Using evidence-based counselling approaches, how should you BEST address her concerns about medication discontinuation?

options.description: Explain she has withdrawal symptoms and must restart medication immediately at the same dose
Discuss that her symptoms suggest discontinuation syndrome, explore her treatment goals, and if she wishes to stop, create a gradual tapering plan after symptom stabilization
Advise that anxiety disorder requires lifelong medication treatment
Suggest switching to benzodiazepines for easier discontinuation in future

question: 18. A 17-year-old female reveals during a routine visit that she's been self-harming by cutting her forearms when feeling overwhelmed by school stress. She shows you several superficial linear scars. She denies suicidal ideation but says cutting helps her 'feel something.' Her parents are unaware. Using trauma-informed care principles, what is the MOST appropriate initial counselling approach?

options.description: Immediately inform her parents as she's a minor at risk
Validate her distress, assess for safety, explore her coping mechanisms, and collaboratively develop a safety plan while discussing confidentiality limits
Refer immediately to emergency psychiatry for admission
Tell her to stop cutting and prescribe an SSRI

question: 19. A 67-year-old man with COPD, heart failure, and diabetes is being discharged after a 5-day admission for COPD exacerbation. During admission, his medications were adjusted: prednisone taper started, furosemide increased, and a new inhaler added. He lives with his wife who has early dementia. To ensure safe transition and reduce readmission risk, which discharge planning intervention has the STRONGEST evidence for effectiveness?

options.description: Provide written discharge instructions in large print
Schedule follow-up with family physician within 30 days
Arrange home visit by nurse practitioner within 48-72 hours for medication reconciliation, teaching, and assessment
Fax discharge summary to family physician

question: 20. You're seeing a 30-year-old woman virtually who's requesting a medical note for work absence due to severe migraine. She describes unilateral throbbing headache with nausea and photophobia, consistent with her previous migraine pattern. She appears distressed on video and requests the note be emailed to her employer today. Considering privacy legislation and professional documentation standards, what is the MOST appropriate approach?

options.description: Email the medical note directly to her employer as requested
Refuse to provide documentation without in-person assessment
Provide a medical note to the patient through secure messaging confirming she was assessed and is unfit for work, without disclosing diagnosis
Document the encounter and tell patient to pick up the note in person
